ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: The course is a little bit out there and undefined...definitely the privilege of being in a small groupwith prof. Grubler far outweighs the drawbacks of dwelling in such an abstract topic.

ETI is one of the best classes I've taken at FES. The class is well-organized with very engaging lectures& readings. It requires a good mix of writing and oral work. TA Rebecca is very helpful and responsive.
Listen to Grubler, he knows his stuff.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: the case studies and the reading responses; i like how people brought in different expertise and expanded our learning beyond the lectures and readings to very practical applications
The readings and lectures in the first half were very informative. Arnulf did a great job of reenforcing the main ideas of the material. The quality of the case studies and the presentations varied.
A very big picture view of technology development and the elements affecting energy systems. Interesting frameworks for understanding how innovations are created and diffused.

1. provide a systemic perspective on energy technology innovations;2. access to Prof. Grubler, TA Rebecca, and a wonderful group of classmates;3. establish a better understanding of various energy technology innovations and the LSM.
Class discussions. The moments when something interesting happened in the online discussion and then for about 10 minutes talked about that in person. Presentations were pretty good too.
Case studies

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: the lsm was very cool and a useful exercise, but it felt a bit like we were guinea pigs--the data website is not quite ready for "prime time"
Working with the LSM model could be reduced to the most important elements.

I would work more on perfecting the use of the frameworks learned in class. It was completely optional to use them in the final paper, and during the blog-discussion sessions they sometimes remained unclear.
more modeling or quantitative examples
People are sheepish around Arnulf, but even he makes mistakes sometimes.
As discussed, some of the LSM data was wrong which was frustrating for students.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I would eliminate the sessions in which each student presents his or her findings of the LSM exercise, and leave more space for discussion on specific examples of energy technologies. I don't believe dividing the analysis by nations sheds any light on what the class is supposed to be about.

The LSM lab was great. It's a nice way to understand the model as well as the IIASA energy database. However, I would recommend the instructor to give more specific instructions (on how to load data and adjust curves etc.) for the lab.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: great conceptual framework for any work within the energy field, i'm sure i'll always hearken back to it when thinking big picture about my career, whether i land on a job in efficiency, renewables, or anything else
The material was very relevant for different aspects. Its focus on energy technologies fitted well into the overall course of my studies.

It fits in really well, although sometimes it's hard to see how because it is so historical and almost philosophical. That's why I would emphasize the practical use of the frameworks reviewed in class.
It fits my concentration (energy and environment) well and I think it's essential to my education.
Energy track at FES, this is pretty good to get some advanced concepts and to understand the possibilities of energy technology policy.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: study energy
Interest in the energy sector
10% for the subject matter and 90% for the instructor. He's just such a fascinating person.
Part of my elective
Grubler is a very good instructor.
Interested in energy technology policy.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
yes

Surpassed my expectations - the course material ended up being very broadly applicable, not only specifically for energy technologies. It taught me to think about technological and institutional transitions from multiple different ankles.

Initially, no, but after I wrote my final paper, which by theway I was not at all pleased with, I discovered that the course had pushed me to think more deeply about important issues and gain insight on them.
Yes
Yes.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: It's great but completely different from ESA.
what's the point in answering this question? students don't get to read the answers when deciding what classes to take.
Do the reading, it's very insightful. Ask Arnulf questions about phenomena/case studies that relate to the course material.

Really do your best to read and participate in class. And take advantage of having the great resource of Arnulf Grubler's time and attention to develop a challenging and interesting paper. I didn't take the time for that and I totally regret it.
1. start the readings as soon as possible. It might take longer than you think;2. outline your final project early;3. engage in the class discussions and happy hours.
Take this if you're an energy person, and don't have an interest in taking a different class that's offered in the fall.
Take it!
